subNodes.conversationText: root
Right beside the path stood a small, girlish being. Knott drew himself up, gripping his weapon. But Pharaoh swooped down from the witch's shoulder and landed at the stranger's feet, cawing happliy.
[Continue.]
"Hello, traveler. I'm Sieben." She had the look of one of the Congress's redcaps without the requisite cap.
The young witch greeted her warily.
"A pleasure."
"If I'm not mistaken, you're part of the Congress of Moths. A fairy."
"Yes, but I don't love the word. I prefer faerie."
[Continue.]
"If I'm not mistaken, you're a witch."
"That's right."
"My brothers and sisters want to kill you, you know."
The young witch demurred.

"You're walking around with a crow and a walking gourd. What else could you be?"

Knott said nothing, of course, but shifted a little at Sieben's remark. Apparently Eldest Lady's spell only hid him from humans.
[Continue.]
"My brothers and sisters want to kill you, you know."
"You don't?"
"I don't even know you!" she said.
"That doesn't stop them."
"I'm not like the rest of my family. I'm not sure why. They never think of anything. I do."
[Continue.]
"Listen, I know why you're here, what you're doing. I can help you."
"Were you here waiting for me?"
"I was waiting for someone to pass by, and you happened to be that person," she equivocated.
[Continue.]
"You have a lot of dross, you know."
"I do? What do you mean?"

"Dross is what we call the residue of desires that used to be. Unshaped, it's useless, worse than nothing. But the Congress has the power to make splendid things from it, and Mother uses it to fashion us, too, and when we come to your world, we feed it to the moths who let us stay in their houses."
"How did I end up with it, and where is it?"
"It doesn't really go places. It changes states, I suppose, but it's never bound to space the way other things are."
[Continue.]
"When we die, the dross of our fairy bodies clings to the person who saw us last. That's why you have so much."
[Continue.]
"My family is -- not likely to go out of their way to help you benefit from all your dross. I am."
"How can you help me, then?"

"I can manipulate dross into a variety of forms. In a few weeks' time these forms perish from your world, but they possess unusual beauty and power before they do. They'll help you in your most difficult battles with the Congress."
"And what happens to the dross after it leaves these items?"

Sieben looked sad. "An astute question. I don't know. I like to think it becomes part of your world, food for your dreams... But sometimes I think Mother hoards it up out of sight. And sometimes I think that it disappears forever,  like the desires that gave it substance, and the people who had them."
"I'm curious."
"I still don't understand. Why help me, when your family seems to oppose me at every turn?"
"I'm curious."
"I still don't understand. Why help me, when your family seems to oppose me at every turn?"

"I'm different. That's all I know," she said.

She was frustrated, the witch saw, but not really by the question.
[Continue.]
"Think of it as a -- benign mystery. Or better yet, don't think of it at all. I don't." Her conclusion was curt but unconvincing.
"How can you help me, then?"
"I'm curious."
"I'm curious."
Sieben proceeded to describe the items she could make and their many wondrous properties.
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
"How do you arrange things with the moths? Do you just show up?"
"The moths' secrets are dull and dusty, but they're still secrets. Anyway --"
[Continue.]
"Why are you telling me this?"
"Because of all the dross you've earned."
[Continue.]
"Dross? What's that?"

"Dross is what we call the residue of desires that used to be. Unshaped, it's useless, worse than nothing. But the Congress has the power to make splendid things from it, and Mother uses it to fashion us, too, and when we come to your world, we feed it to the moths who let us stay in their houses."
"But 'dross' simply means rubbish. Should I be confused or merely insulted?"
"The word has another meaning for me and my kind."
[Continue.]

"Dross is what we call the residue of desires that used to be. Unshaped, it's useless, worse than nothing. But the Congress has the power to make splendid things from it, and Mother uses it to fashion us, too, and when we come to your world, we feed it to the moths who let us stay in their houses."
"What kind of help?"
"I can make things you'd find useful."
[Continue.]
"Then maybe we should stay strangers."
"I mean you no harm."
[Continue.]
"I'm not like the rest of my family. I'm not sure why. They never think of anything. I do."
"I'm aware of their murderous intentions."
"Don't worry."
[Continue.]
"I'm not like the rest of my family. I'm not sure why. They never think of anything. I do."
"They're welcome to keep trying. I can handle them."
"That's good, because they will keep trying."
[Continue.]
"I know. Why is that?"
"Don't expect me to enlighten you."
[Continue.]
"I'm not like the rest of my family. I'm not sure why. They never think of anything. I do."
"Wych, actually."
"My brothers and sisters want to kill you, you know."
"Those crystals -- What are they?"
"These? I made them. They're only here because I wanted to attract someone's attention."
[Continue.]
"How goes it?"
"Well enough."
[Continue.]
"If I'm not mistaken, you're a witch."
<FirstName> smiled and gave <his/her> name.
"A pleasure."

The witch came upon a strange being sitting by the side of the path. She was short and elfin-looking, like one of the Congress of Moths. She greeted <FirstName> by name and explained that she knew all about <him/her> and <his/her> doings.
"Were you sitting here waiting for me?"
"I was waiting for someone to pass by, and you happened to be that person," she equivocated.
[Continue.]

"My name's Sieben. You've already met some of my brothers and sisters -- but don't worry, I don't kill things. I make them -- with dross. You say dross and think rubbish, zero worth, but for me and my kin, dross is everything. You happen to have collected some."
"You know a lot about me, but I don't know anything about you."

"My name's Sieben. You've already met some of my brothers and sisters -- but don't worry, I don't kill things. I make them -- with dross. You say dross and think rubbish, zero worth, but for me and my kin, dross is everything. You happen to have collected some."
"Dross is everything? What do you mean?"

She thought something over, then replied:

"How can I put this?... Dross is the residue of human desires that used to be. Some desires are satisfied and die; some fade; some cease with their owners' lives. All leave dross behind. The Wooden Crone uses it to make me and my siblings."
"Why would a satisfied desire leave any trace of itself behind?"
"All desire is a square peg, and all fulfillment a round hole that, if it accepts the peg, has to shave off some of its corners. Those shavings become dross."
"And you are made of this residue?"
"More or less. We have an ancient pact with the moths of this world. They house us here, and in return we bring them dross, the wine they love, that makes them drunk on candelight."
"And what did you mean when you said that I've collected dross?"

"When we die in this world, the dross separates from the moth that housed it. Disincarnate, it clings to the nearest desire, as iron nails fly and cling to lodestone -- different substances that share the same nature.

"I can see the dross all around you. I can even measure it. It's there, ready to be reshaped, though it's invisible to your eyes."
[Continue.]

"I can make things out of dross that will help you. In a few weeks' time, they'll fade -- just as I and my siblings do if someone doesn't come along and snap our threads first. But while they exist they have unusual beauty and power."
"Why help me at all? The rest of your kind opposes me at every step."
"Think of it as a -- benign riddle. Or better yet, don't think of it at all."
"I'm curious."
"I'm curious."
"But how exactly does an emotional residue become real?"
"A question a magician might ask. Be a witch and tolerate the mystery."
"I have nothing else to ask."
"Really? How exactly does an emotional residue become real?"
"A question a magician might ask. Be a witch and tolerate the mystery."
"Why would a satisfied desire leave any trace of itself behind?"
"All desire is a square peg, and all fulfillment a round hole that, if it accepts the peg, has to shave off some of its corners. Those shavings become dross."
"What did you mean when you said that I have collected dross?"

"When we die in this world, the dross separates from the moth that housed it. Disincarnate, it clings to the nearest desire, as iron nails fly and cling to lodestone -- different substances that share the same nature.

"I can see the dross all around you. I can even measure it. It's there, ready to be reshaped, though it's invisible to your eyes."
"You're not made of flesh in the way that I am. Is that why you don't leave bodies behind?"
"More or less. We have an ancient pact with the moths of this world. They house us here, and in return we bring them dross, the wine they love, that makes them drunk on candelight."
"I have nothing else to ask."

"I can make things out of dross that will help you. In a few weeks' time, they'll fade -- just as I and my siblings do if someone doesn't come along and snap our threads first. But while they exist they have unusual beauty and power."
"So you're not physical like I am. That's why you vanish."
"More or less. We have an ancient pact with the moths of this world. They house us here, and in return we bring them dross, the wine they love, that makes them drunk on candelight."
"What did you mean when you said that I have collected dross?"
"I'm still confused. How exactly does an emotional residue become real?"
"A question a magician might ask. Be a witch and tolerate the mystery."
"I have nothing else to ask."
"And what did you mean when you said that I've collected dross?"
"I see," said the witch, not quite understanding.

"I can make things out of dross that will help you. In a few weeks' time, they'll fade -- just as I and my siblings do if someone doesn't come along and snap our threads first. But while they exist they have unusual beauty and power."
"I don't understand what you're saying."

She thought something over, then replied:

"How can I put this?... Dross is the residue of human desires that used to be. Some desires are satisfied and die; some fade; some cease with their owners' lives. All leave dross behind. The Wooden Crone uses it to make me and my siblings."
"I do?"

She thought something over, then replied:

"How can I put this?... Dross is the residue of human desires that used to be. Some desires are satisfied and die; some fade; some cease with their owners' lives. All leave dross behind. The Wooden Crone uses it to make me and my siblings."
"Hello again. More dross?"
"Yes, I think."
Sieben once again described the jewels she could make.
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
"No, but I do have questions for you."
"You think I know more than you. And perhaps I do -- but that doesn't mean I can just tell you everything."
"Do you know why the Congress of Moths is here?"
"See? That's just what I'm talking about."
"Why not talk freely? You defy your family in other ways."
"What about Nnenne? Do you know anything about the hunter who killed her?"
"Not as much as you're destined to find out," she said evasively.
"Why not talk freely? You defy your family in other ways."
"Fate is less easily defied, and it's my fate to be bound by different rules than the ones that bind you."
"Very well. Goodbye."
"So be it. Meanwhile, I'm considering getting a dross stone after all."
Sieben once again described the jewels she could make.
"Do you know anything about the hunter who killed Nnenne?"
"Not as much as you're destined to find out," she said evasively.
"Why not talk freely? You defy your family in other ways."
"Very well. Goodbye."
"So be it. Meanwhile, I'm considering getting a dross stone after all."
"I want to know more about Malkin."
"See? That's just what I'm talking about."
"Very well. Goodbye."
"No, I'm just passing by. Farewell."
